messageBody:
Mike Clark wrote:

> > How about Bill Wake's Spreadsheet idea <http://www.xp123.com/xplor/
> > xp0201/>?
>
> Just to share what has worked well for me...
>
> In my TDD workshop we start with the Spreadsheet and then move on to
> a shopping cart application, just to give a couple different
> perspectives. Some folks resonate more with one than another.


Along these lines, are JUnit and Java prerequisites for the course? By
GUI do you mean a fat client or will a webapp suffice? If JUnit and
Java are not prerequisites and a thin client is sufficient, doing a
shopping cart application in Squeak or VisualWorks with SUnit could
prove very easy for the facilitator (something I always go for when
doing workshops) and you could easily morph this into a GUI app by using
Seaside (a webapp framework). You could even pick up some rudimentary
ideas from the Sushi Online Store sample application.

One tack I take in doing these types of workshops is to concentrate on
unit testing skills, not language issues. I therefore tend to choose a
language platform that is unfamiliar to the wider audience. This helps
the audience to not get caught up in implementation details (eg. coding
styles, method names, etc.) because if it is a language they are
unfamiliar with they will tend not to bother about those things. YMMV

--
